description: Digital Forensic Investigator guides you through the process of performing a forensic investigation and is for someone who is going to be doing corporate or criminal investigations that may include collecting, preserving and analyzing evidence and getting it ready to be presented in court. Viewers will learn the steps involved in performing an investigation, from securing the crime scene, to collecting and processing the evidence, and reporting the findings and hear about some of the certifications one can achieve to prove their knowledge in this area, which is important knowledge for all IT security personnel, giving you the knowledge needed to respond properly in the event of a security incident.
name: Digital Forensic Investigator
subtitle: Information retrieval and protection

34

35

I also throw in to this

There is a difference between those

38

39

That they're literally if you

40

that stuff that the computer itself

41

Page file that is something

00:03:00,350 --> 00:03:02,860
there is stuff in it, that is another one.

00:03:02,860 --> 00:03:07,360
User generated stuff would be things that
for example, you had direct influence put

48
00:03:07,360 --> 00:03:12,600

type it in to a database or what have you.

49
00:03:12,600 --> 00:03:17,130
That's what that sort is so it kind of
adds interesting rub to this whole thing

50
00:03:17,130 --> 00:03:21,310
because we would normally think about
the latter and not the former type.

51
00:03:21,310 --> 00:03:23,290
User generated, not computer generated.

52
00:03:23,290 --> 00:03:24,210
>> Right.

53
00:03:24,210 --> 00:03:27,360
And all that can be affected by
policies in the systems that

54
00:03:28,820 --> 00:03:32,400
the bad guy was using whether

55
00:03:32,400 --> 00:03:35,540
how detailed of auditing that it was

56
00:03:35,540 --> 00:03:36,720
It really is surprising.

57
00:03:36,720 --> 00:03:40,120

58
00:03:40,120 --> 00:03:41,600

As one of the examples we turn on auditing

00:03:45,530 --> 00:03:49,210
user and go double click on it or what

61
00:03:49,210 --> 00:03:53,130

62
00:03:53,130 --> 00:03:57,490
So there's all kinds of places that we

63

64

65

If you guys have not

69
00:04:12,650 --> 00:04:14,990
They're gonna be doing different
types of techniques to try and

70

71

But, we go back to Lockheed I think is

00:04:20,060 --> 00:04:21,850
the guy,

>> Any contact is going to

So in our investigation we

77

We've all seen the different crime shows

00:04:42,710 --> 00:04:44,046

00:04:44,046 --> 00:04:47,056

digital data a little bit different.

We got to handle it a different way,
we got to treat it a different way.

84
00:04:57,230 --> 00:05:01,880
I would talk as much as some of the issues
that we have with digital evidence.

85
00:05:01,880 --> 00:05:04,050

Reason why we're going through

00:05:09,920 --> 00:05:14,680

We're no longer just looking at,

00:05:58,680 --> 00:06:02,820

101
00:06:02,820 --> 00:06:05,580

00:06:05,580 --> 00:06:07,640
it just depends on if

103
00:06:07,640 --> 00:06:12,430
In fact, I've got a really good friend

00:06:12,430 --> 00:06:14,730

Perfect, he really crystallized up this

00:06:19,611 --> 00:06:21,561
that's what he does by the way.

00:06:23,926 --> 00:06:27,550
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That's nice.

00:06:27,550 --> 00:06:28,800
>> He's been doing it for years.

00:06:28,800 --> 00:06:33,140
I was like, I don't know if

00:06:33,140 --> 00:06:34,140
>> Yeah, yeah.

Maybe not as easy to do, but

00:06:35,860 --> 00:06:40,645

00:06:40,645 --> 00:06:44,400
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, if you can slide under the radar

00:06:44,400 --> 00:06:47,680

116
00:06:50,620 --> 00:06:53,700

117
00:06:53,700 --> 00:06:58,940
You might be able to prevent or

118
00:06:58,940 --> 00:06:59,470
>> Right.

119
00:06:59,470 --> 00:07:02,510
And one of the first things we probably
need to talk about with digital evidence

120
00:07:02,510 --> 00:07:04,870
is, is it a little different than
a lot of our physical evidence?

121
00:07:04,870 --> 00:07:07,780
If I find a weapon, and
I put in an evidence bag and I seal it up.

122
00:07:07,780 --> 00:07:11,890
And I put it in a box, put it in a car,
put it on a shelf at work, what have you.

123
00:07:11,890 --> 00:07:15,360
That weapon is still gonna be a weapon and
I didn't really change anything about it.

124
00:07:15,360 --> 00:07:18,140
But with digital evidence,
a little bit different.

125
00:07:18,140 --> 00:07:23,590
I mean, it's so
easy to accidentally modify this evidence.

126
00:07:23,590 --> 00:07:27,400
Cuz it's not like a physical piece

127
00:07:27,400 --> 00:07:28,970
We're talking about
things on a hard drive.

128
00:07:28,970 --> 00:07:31,240
We're talking about metadata for
these documents.

129
00:07:31,240 --> 00:07:33,790
We're talking about things
that are stored in ram or

130
00:07:33,790 --> 00:07:38,230
in page files and we all know there's
gonna be some issues trying to capture.

131
00:07:38,230 --> 00:07:41,270
Or it's very easy to
destroy that type of data.

132
00:07:41,270 --> 00:07:41,790
>> Mm-hm.

133
00:07:41,790 --> 00:07:42,530
Absolutely.

134
00:07:42,530 --> 00:07:43,250
Volatility.

135
00:07:43,250 --> 00:07:43,900
Volatility.

136
00:07:43,900 --> 00:07:44,584
Volatility.

137
00:07:44,584 --> 00:07:49,243
Is probably the biggest thing that
you're gonna have that's gonna impact,

138
00:07:49,243 --> 00:07:54,046
or one of the biggest things you're gonna
have that impacts how good evidence is

139
00:07:54,046 --> 00:07:56,567

00:07:56,567 --> 00:08:00,878
We actually have three criteria we're
gonna talk about as we get further

00:08:00,878 --> 00:08:01,720
into it.

142
00:08:01,720 --> 00:08:05,600
There's a certain way to collect evidence.

143
00:08:06,810 --> 00:08:11,730
Let's talk about going back
to something we had when

144
00:08:11,730 --> 00:08:15,400
we talked about modern forensics and
forensic science.

145
00:08:15,400 --> 00:08:17,350
We talked about what forensics does.

146
00:08:17,350 --> 00:08:20,020
We talked about we talked
about the first part of it,

147
00:08:20,020 --> 00:08:22,070
cuz it's really responsible for
a couple of things.

148
00:08:22,070 --> 00:08:26,690
If you focus on the first part,
that was collect and preserve.

149
00:08:26,690 --> 00:08:28,910
So, when we talk about digital evidence,

150
00:08:28,910 --> 00:08:33,375
we got to figure out a way to collect it,
and preserve it at the same time.

151
00:08:33,375 --> 00:08:36,105
Both those things have to be accomplished.

152
00:08:36,105 --> 00:08:37,655
It can definitely be,

153
00:08:37,655 --> 00:08:41,765
to borrow something from one of our
viewers out there, it can be a puzzle.

154
00:08:41,765 --> 00:08:42,505
It really can.

155
00:08:42,505 --> 00:08:46,375
Sometimes you may even be faced with hey,
I have to sacrifice this,

156
00:08:46,375 --> 00:08:50,425
to get this, cuz this is more reliable
evidence, you might very well have that.

157
00:08:51,530 --> 00:08:53,060
There are certain things.

158
00:08:53,060 --> 00:08:57,310
In fact, some of the ways we collect
evidence due to it's volatility and

159
00:08:57,310 --> 00:09:00,960
reliability will fly counter to some of
the things that you have seen done in

160
00:09:00,960 --> 00:09:01,630
the past.

161
00:09:01,630 --> 00:09:05,850
Like I have said a couple of times
already, today how you shut down

162
00:09:05,850 --> 00:09:11,640
a computer, that can definitely
impact how you collect evidence or

163
00:09:11,640 --> 00:09:14,210
what evidence your gonna have
to collect in the first place.

164
00:09:14,210 --> 00:09:14,760
>> Right.

165
00:09:14,760 --> 00:09:18,500
We've got a whole episode about being
the first res-ponder and things like that.

166
00:09:18,500 --> 00:09:19,480
>> Oh yeah.

167
00:09:19,480 --> 00:09:20,580
If you come up to a gear,

168
00:09:20,580 --> 00:09:23,240
your boss calls you in oh my gosh I
think this machine's been hacked.

169
00:09:23,240 --> 00:09:25,870
Something's going on,
I need you to gather evidence.

170
00:09:25,870 --> 00:09:28,720
If you're not trained properly or
you panic or

171
00:09:28,720 --> 00:09:33,100
what have you, you go in there unplugging
that machine, or powering it down and

172
00:09:33,100 --> 00:09:36,030
you've just lost a good chunk
of your evidence, right,

173
00:09:36,030 --> 00:09:39,830
because we know that a lot of information
is stored in RAM, which is volatile.

174
00:09:39,830 --> 00:09:41,340
Power that machine down.

175
00:09:41,340 --> 00:09:42,740
That information is gone.

176
00:09:42,740 --> 00:09:44,490
A lot of it's stored in my page file.

177
00:09:44,490 --> 00:09:46,340
That could be valuable
information there and

178
00:09:46,340 --> 00:09:49,280
if I power that machine down I
could lose that information.

179
00:09:49,280 --> 00:09:52,460
So we've gotta make sure we
understand the types of evidence.

180
00:09:52,460 --> 00:09:56,784
Where we can look, and what their
validity or Where their volatility is so

181
00:09:56,784 --> 00:09:59,029
we can process it in the proper order.

182
00:09:59,029 --> 00:10:05,020
You wanna go for the highly volatile
stuff first before it goes away.

183
00:10:05,020 --> 00:10:08,770
>> And
what we should do is talk just to kinda,

184
00:10:08,770 --> 00:10:14,850
add to that volatility
part,is the idea of the three

185
00:10:14,850 --> 00:10:20,330
criteria is we're talking about evidence,
we're talking about how fragile it is,

186
00:10:20,330 --> 00:10:26,730
some evidence, just by doing a little
bit of stuff, it can be obliterated.

187
00:10:26,730 --> 00:10:30,480
Some stuff has a very short lifespan.

188
00:10:30,480 --> 00:10:32,920
For example, the stuff in memory.

189
00:10:32,920 --> 00:10:36,450
Stuff in memory would definitely
have a short live span.

190
00:10:36,450 --> 00:10:41,030
If you turn that computer off
you will lose that information.

191
00:10:41,030 --> 00:10:47,320
So, in terms of volatility, that's way up
near the top, it's very highly volatile so

192
00:10:47,320 --> 00:10:52,540
you need to figure out if that computer
is on, how are you gonna collect it?

193
00:10:52,540 --> 00:10:56,450
If the computer's off, then clearly
there's not anything in memory, but

194

technical and expect a CEO to get it,

2198
01:55:42,053 --> 01:55:47,402
unless, it's a small company and
that CEO is very technical-oriented.

2199
01:55:47,402 --> 01:55:49,005
But that still gonna have a limit.

2200
01:55:49,005 --> 01:55:53,574
If it goes into court, you present
something that's overly technical,

2201
01:55:53,574 --> 01:55:55,645
it's just not gonna hold water.

2202
01:55:55,645 --> 01:55:58,345
And I know that one is
pretty much a fact as far as

2203
01:55:58,345 --> 01:56:01,821
presenting something that's
overly technical in court.

2204
01:56:01,821 --> 01:56:05,722
It could very well turn out bad for
you and in a lot of cases it will.

2205
01:56:05,722 --> 01:56:10,645
The legal system is still learning the
cyber stuff as much as they want to say,

2206
01:56:10,645 --> 01:56:12,559
oh yeah, we've got it down.

2207
01:56:12,559 --> 01:56:17,474
Yeah, they're writing new laws on this
all the time, and the law lawyers

2208
01:56:17,474 --> 01:56:22,466
that are going to court now, the ones
that are redoing high profile cases,

2209
01:56:22,466 --> 01:56:25,341
and the judges who've gone in the system.

2210
01:56:25,341 --> 01:56:28,997
When they were in law school,
they were using pad and paper, and

2211
01:56:28,997 --> 01:56:31,785
they're still accustomed
to that a lot of them.

2212
01:56:31,785 --> 01:56:36,927
And so, they whatever the new stuff,
I'm gonna retire in a few years.

2213
01:56:36,927 --> 01:56:40,490
They don't really care, or
I shouldn't say don't care,

2214
01:56:40,490 --> 01:56:42,779
I'm gonna get ticketed so bad today.

2215
01:56:42,779 --> 01:56:45,084
So,
>> [LAUGH] We're looking for that Sean.

2216
01:56:45,084 --> 01:56:46,361
[CROSSTALK] You see,
>> Yeah

2217
01:56:46,361 --> 01:56:48,369
>> He's driving a black Ferrari [LAUGH]

2218
01:56:48,369 --> 01:56:53,206
>> Yeah, why don't you just give

2219
01:56:53,206 --> 01:56:56,004
me a nice red car?

2220
01:56:56,004 --> 01:57:00,968
That's what's gonna happen and it very
well could happen if you mix up too overly

2221
01:57:00,968 --> 01:57:03,828
technical, it could very well, impede you.

2222
01:57:03,828 --> 01:57:06,699
And, like I said, I know for a fact,

2223
01:57:06,699 --> 01:57:12,724
I know someone I can think of right off
the top of my head, that went to court and

2224
01:57:12,724 --> 01:57:17,453
I have no doubt that they were
pretty versed in the field, but

2225
01:57:17,453 --> 01:57:22,368
that they did is they told both
lawyers and the judge they said,

2226
01:57:22,368 --> 01:57:26,983
I will explain the technical
details to you if you need to.

2227
01:57:26,983 --> 01:57:31,244
And both of them,
all parties were, nah, whatever.

2228
01:57:31,244 --> 01:57:36,097
One of the lawyers actually wrote
the stuff down and screwed it all up.

2229
01:57:36,097 --> 01:57:36,827
>> Oh, no.

2230
01:57:36,827 --> 01:57:38,941
>> Yeah, so,
>> [LAUGH]

2231
01:57:38,941 --> 01:57:40,624
>> Be prepared for that.

2232
01:57:40,624 --> 01:57:45,386
Try to make stuff that is factual, have
your evidence there in your report, but

2233
01:57:45,386 --> 01:57:48,156
also try to as much as
possible to stow that down

2234
01:57:48,156 --> 01:57:51,665
into something that's a little
more easy to understand.

2235
01:57:51,665 --> 01:57:55,020
And then they have the other
stuff there as needed.

2236
01:57:55,020 --> 01:57:55,577
>> Got you.

2237
01:57:55,577 --> 01:57:58,386
So, you can fill it in if they need a
little lot more detail, I've got it there.

2238
01:57:58,386 --> 01:58:01,103
But maybe not to provide it all up front.

2239
01:58:01,103 --> 01:58:05,085
>> Yeah, and make yourself
available to interpret stuff, too.

2240
01:58:05,085 --> 01:58:09,961
>> All right, well, ladies and gentlemen,
that is going to do it for our show today.

2241
01:58:09,961 --> 01:58:11,482
Went through a lot of information there.

2242
01:58:11,482 --> 01:58:14,105
We did our computer forensics
investigation process.

2243
01:58:14,105 --> 01:58:18,754
We just, basically, walked through
the entire phase starting with what our

2244
01:58:18,754 --> 01:58:23,619
goals were, different types of computer
crimes that we might have to deal with,

2245
01:58:23,619 --> 01:58:27,143
and then, we moved in to making
sure we secured the scene.

2246
01:58:27,143 --> 01:58:29,023
And we, actually, did a nice little demo.

2247
01:58:29,023 --> 01:58:33,264
We showed you guys what it might be like,
walking into a place, securing the scene,

2248
01:58:33,264 --> 01:58:37,388
collecting that evidence, bagging and
tagging it and getting it back to the lab,

2249
01:58:37,388 --> 01:58:39,402
so that we can do our further analysis.

2250
01:58:39,402 --> 01:58:42,645
I would take a look at some
of those analytical processes

2251
01:58:42,645 --> 01:58:45,475
here in just a little bit,
or in our future show.

2252
01:58:45,475 --> 01:58:49,201
We also talked about what we might be
doing once we got that evidence back.

2253
01:58:49,201 --> 01:58:53,938
We gotta analyze that data, going
through all those different log files,

2254
01:58:53,938 --> 01:58:58,599
as well as generating our reports that
we can deliver to whomever it is that

2255
01:58:58,599 --> 01:59:02,076
wanted us to do this
investigation in the first place.

2256
01:59:02,076 --> 01:59:04,561
So, I hoped you guys enjoyed the show.

2257
01:59:04,561 --> 01:59:07,345
Remember, if you're watching
the show live and you got questions,

2258
01:59:07,345 --> 01:59:09,320
all you gotta do is jump
in that chat room and ask.

2259
01:59:09,320 --> 01:59:09,854
We're sitting here.

2260
01:59:09,854 --> 01:59:11,339
We've got the chat room
right in front of us.

2261
01:59:11,339 --> 01:59:13,662
We'll answer your questions live on air.

2262
01:59:13,662 --> 01:59:16,101
If you're watching and
recording this show, don't worry.

2263
01:59:16,101 --> 01:59:17,378
You can still ask questions.

2264
01:59:17,378 --> 01:59:20,396
Up at the top of every page is a Q and
A link.

2265
01:59:20,396 --> 01:59:21,301
Click on that.

2266
01:59:21,301 --> 01:59:22,300
It takes you to our forums.

2267
01:59:22,300 --> 01:59:23,937
You can post your questions there.

2268
01:59:23,937 --> 01:59:26,816
We monitor those and
we'll get the answer you need.

2269
01:59:26,816 --> 01:59:28,860
So, again, thanks for tuning in.

2270
01:59:28,860 --> 01:59:31,600
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Mike Rodrick.

2271
01:59:31,600 --> 01:59:34,200
>> And I'm Sean, tag it and
bag it, Oriyano.

2272
01:59:34,200 --> 01:59:36,000
And we'll see you next time.

2273

episodes.title: First Responder Procedures
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:15,356 --> 00:00:23,785
[SOUND]

3
00:00:23,785 --> 00:00:32,957
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:32,957 --> 00:00:35,140
Good morning, good afternoon,
and good evening.

5
00:00:35,140 --> 00:00:37,330
Welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:37,330 --> 00:00:39,830
I'm your host Mike Broderick and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriano.

7
00:00:39,830 --> 00:00:41,800
How are you doing, Sean?

8
00:00:41,800 --> 00:00:43,090
>> Pretty good, how are you doing?

9
00:00:43,090 --> 00:00:44,260
>> I'm doing fantastic.

10
00:00:44,260 --> 00:00:46,680
Looking forward to
another exciting episode

11
00:00:46,680 --> 00:00:49,730
in our digital forensic
investigator series.

12
00:00:49,730 --> 00:00:51,210
In this episode in particular,

13
00:00:51,210 --> 00:00:54,050
we're going to be going over
the first responder procedures.

14
00:00:54,050 --> 00:00:59,040
So talking about what it is to be that
first responder that first person to

15
00:00:59,040 --> 00:01:03,790
be at the scene of the crime or
wherever the incident has occurred, and

16
00:01:03,790 --> 00:01:04,510
what we need to do.

17
00:01:04,510 --> 00:01:06,330
What we need to be aware of.

18
00:01:06,330 --> 00:01:09,150
Techniques we might use,
being that first on the scene,

19
00:01:09,150 --> 00:01:11,780
because that first person is
a little bit special, right?

20
00:01:11,780 --> 00:01:12,770
>> Yes!

21
00:01:12,770 --> 00:01:15,477
They do have a very special
role in the whole process.

22
00:01:16,760 --> 00:01:20,930
It's very important to
understand who that person is,

23
00:01:20,930 --> 00:01:24,850
what that person's expected to do,
give them their responsibilities.

24
00:01:24,850 --> 00:01:28,060
There are just a lot of things,
a lot of details.

25
00:01:28,060 --> 00:01:31,710
Keep in mind you as
a forensic investigator

26
00:01:31,710 --> 00:01:33,490
may not be the first responder.

27
00:01:33,490 --> 00:01:35,440
You may not have that luxury.

28
00:01:35,440 --> 00:01:41,930
So it very well could be someone else I
think it would be important for us to kind

29
00:01:41,930 --> 00:01:47,880
of really state who a first responder is
to kinda clear up any confusion with that.

30
00:01:47,880 --> 00:01:52,750
So a first responder, by definition,
is the first person on the scene.

31
00:01:52,750 --> 00:01:54,050
I know it sounds kind of like.

32
00:01:55,160 --> 00:01:57,903
But they really are the first
person on the scene.

33
00:01:57,903 --> 00:01:58,533
>> [LAUGH] Wait?

34
00:01:58,533 --> 00:02:00,345
What?
>> Yeah, it's like, write that down,

35
00:02:00,345 --> 00:02:01,110
what did you say?

36
00:02:01,110 --> 00:02:01,730
Yeah.

37
00:02:01,730 --> 00:02:05,550
It is the first person on the scene, but

38
00:02:05,550 --> 00:02:10,620
it's typically if
an incident has happened and

39
00:02:10,620 --> 00:02:14,970
it gets reported, this is the person
that does show up at that point.

40
00:02:14,970 --> 00:02:18,930
And if that person happen to be you,
then you are the first responder, and

41
00:02:18,930 --> 00:02:22,110
you can determine how best
to proceed from that point.

42
00:02:22,110 --> 00:02:27,630
If it's not you, then you have to give
guidance to someone on how to handle that.

43
00:02:27,630 --> 00:02:30,940
I mean, if you work in a company that's
large enough or a situation that's large

44
00:02:30,940 --> 00:02:35,800
enough, that office that has the security
incident may be on the other side of town.

45
00:02:35,800 --> 00:02:38,410
It's gonna take you time to grab your kit.

46
00:02:38,410 --> 00:02:40,570
And drive over there.

47
00:02:40,570 --> 00:02:43,520
So you've really gotta
take that into account.

48
00:02:43,520 --> 00:02:48,750
So a first responder is kinda be
your eyes and ears on the ground.

49
00:02:48,750 --> 00:02:51,551
And it's gonna be the person
that is responsible for

50
00:02:51,551 --> 00:02:55,280
controlling that scene
until you get there.

51
00:02:55,280 --> 00:02:58,690
>> Yeah, exactly, so
whether we're the first responder or not,

52
00:02:58,690 --> 00:03:03,530
we need to be aware of what
the expectations really are of that first

53
00:03:03,530 --> 00:03:09,150
responder and be able to potentially train
people to be that first responder or.

54
00:03:09,150 --> 00:03:11,530
Talk somebody through being
that first responder.

55
00:03:11,530 --> 00:03:14,770
If it is just another
employee at the company, and

56
00:03:14,770 --> 00:03:18,700
we've got to be able to
tell them what to do.

57
00:03:18,700 --> 00:03:20,980
And what we expect of them.

58
00:03:20,980 --> 00:03:23,240
So that's why it's important for
us to know.

59
00:03:23,240 --> 00:03:26,974
Not to mention it could be on your exams
depending on which one you are taking.

60
00:03:26,974 --> 00:03:31,580
>> It will definitely be in those
situations because the first responder

61
00:03:31,580 --> 00:03:33,680
is part of your team.

62
00:03:33,680 --> 00:03:36,900
I would also throw into this when
we talk about a first responder,

63
00:03:36,900 --> 00:03:40,189
technically anybody that shows up
there first is the first responder.

64
00:03:41,260 --> 00:03:44,900
So you could beat virgin
Eric in that sense, but

65
00:03:44,900 --> 00:03:46,460
the first responder we're looking for

66
00:03:46,460 --> 00:03:51,430
is someone who has a little bit of
a higher standard of familiarity with it.

67
00:03:51,430 --> 00:03:54,460
They are probably not going
to be a laboratory staff,

68
00:03:54,460 --> 00:03:57,020
they're going to be non laboratory staff.

69
00:03:57,020 --> 00:03:59,240
With us being laboratory and them not.

70
00:03:59,240 --> 00:04:01,700
So, that's the kind of situation.

71
00:04:01,700 --> 00:04:05,060
We see them as on that side of the fence.

72
00:04:05,060 --> 00:04:09,050
One thing I like to do is when we're
talking about this process, one of

73
00:04:09,050 --> 00:04:13,750
the things I think is not a bad idea for
you to consider doing in your environment.

74
00:04:13,750 --> 00:04:17,770
Is if you have people in different
locations that are first responders,

75
00:04:17,770 --> 00:04:22,700
you guys should get to know one another,
before an incident happens.

76
00:04:22,700 --> 00:04:25,640
You don't want to be like,
who the heck is this.

77
00:04:25,640 --> 00:04:27,810
You want to have that familiarity.

78
00:04:27,810 --> 00:04:29,880
You also want to, if you can,

79
00:04:29,880 --> 00:04:35,360
kind of let them in on the type of things
that, how your side of things work.

80
00:04:35,360 --> 00:04:37,720
I mean, your the one that's
gonna be writing procedures or

81
00:04:37,720 --> 00:04:40,170
having input on procedures
on how they're gonna react.

82
00:04:40,170 --> 00:04:43,660
You should let them know a little
bit more, as much as you can.

83
00:04:43,660 --> 00:04:46,450
About why you're asking for
this, and what you do, so

84
00:04:46,450 --> 00:04:50,470
you can kinda get a more closer fit and
get what you need.

85
00:04:50,470 --> 00:04:53,285
It's just the best for everybody.

86
00:04:53,285 --> 00:04:54,790
>> Mm-hm.

87
00:04:54,790 --> 00:04:55,570
All right.

88
00:04:55,570 --> 00:04:58,110
So what do we do as a first responder?

89
00:04:58,110 --> 00:05:00,780
What should we be telling
them to do first?

90
00:05:00,780 --> 00:05:02,910
There are a few things that hop to mind.

91
00:05:02,910 --> 00:05:06,200
Securing [INAUDIBLE] and a few of you
in the chat room have already said,

92
00:05:06,200 --> 00:05:09,200
paying attention,
watching our previous episodes.

93
00:05:09,200 --> 00:05:11,730
They've already started throwing
out lots of good ideas.

94
00:05:11,730 --> 00:05:13,290
Lock down the area.

95
00:05:13,290 --> 00:05:16,990
Lock down any personnel
that might be in the area,

96
00:05:16,990 --> 00:05:18,960
any devices that might be in the area.

97
00:05:18,960 --> 00:05:21,570
Make sure that they're not removed and
things like that.

98
00:05:21,570 --> 00:05:23,050
But where is a good place to start?

99
00:05:23,050 --> 00:05:25,710
I know you've got like electronic
evidence in our list of

100
00:05:25,710 --> 00:05:27,080
things we need to talk about.

101
00:05:27,080 --> 00:05:28,670
>> Yes, there is electronic evidence.

102
00:05:28,670 --> 00:05:33,350
We talked about some of the various forms
of electronic evidence yesterday, and

103
00:05:33,350 --> 00:05:35,260
the way evidence works.

104
00:05:35,260 --> 00:05:39,170
We're more concerned with the physical
stuff that's there, as well as,

105
00:05:39,170 --> 00:05:43,820
we can talk about the physical stuff,
but the electronic evidence as well.

106
00:05:43,820 --> 00:05:47,480
People need to know how, or
the first responder need to know,

107
00:05:47,480 --> 00:05:51,878
about the nature of electronic evidence
and things they should and shouldn't do.

108
00:05:51,878 --> 00:05:57,365
There been some really goofy things that
people have done over the years that have,

109
00:05:57,365 --> 00:06:00,265
screwed things up royally
because they don't know

110
00:06:00,265 --> 00:06:01,835
how to handle electronic evidence.

111
00:06:01,835 --> 00:06:04,785
They might have the best
intentions they're just there,

112
00:06:04,785 --> 00:06:08,645
on the scene, they're just not
trained in it they don't know.

113
00:06:08,645 --> 00:06:11,575
So, we have to kind of guide them.

114
00:06:11,575 --> 00:06:15,649
And maybe we're a private firm like
a security firm that does this forensics.

115
00:06:16,680 --> 00:06:19,680
So if we're getting contracted
by some business to be their

116
00:06:19,680 --> 00:06:24,680
forensic investigators, they might have
individuals on staff at the company,

117
00:06:24,680 --> 00:06:28,310
say we need one of your employees to come
and talk to us so we can kind of train

118
00:06:28,310 --> 00:06:33,560
enough to be that first responder, or
that first response incident team that can

119
00:06:33,560 --> 00:06:35,870
get things ready for us to get there or
something like that.

120
00:06:35,870 --> 00:06:39,550
>> Yeah, it's definitely not a bad idea,
and I would always kind of,

121
00:06:39,550 --> 00:06:45,835
to coin a phrase, have that rule of two
at every site where you've got a primary.

122
00:06:45,835 --> 00:06:46,955
And you got a secondary so

123
00:06:46,955 --> 00:06:49,675
there's always someone there to
cover if there is an incident.

124
00:06:49,675 --> 00:06:53,625
So whatever happens
you've got that coverage.

125
00:06:53,625 --> 00:06:56,895
Yeah, let them know what
they're supposed to do,

126
00:06:56,895 --> 00:06:59,545
and what they're not supposed to do.

127
00:06:59,545 --> 00:07:02,055
If you don't do that you're
going to end up with

128
00:07:02,055 --> 00:07:06,150
some real kind of bad things happening.

129
00:07:06,150 --> 00:07:10,260
One that I can think of that we're
gonna follow up on here in a bit

130
00:07:10,260 --> 00:07:15,200
that's not uncommon is if you put
a scenario out there to someone

131
00:07:15,200 --> 00:07:19,850
saying a crime was committed, and
you painted some scenario where they had,

132
00:07:19,850 --> 00:07:23,620
the layperson had to secure that scene.

133
00:07:23,620 --> 00:07:27,220
And our situation, they might very
well secure the scene by saying okay,

134
00:07:27,220 --> 00:07:30,470
I'm gonna turn off all the computers and
shoo everyone away.

135
00:07:30,470 --> 00:07:31,730
That's what they're gonna do.

136
00:07:31,730 --> 00:07:36,280
And the thing is that's
just totally wrong.

137
00:07:36,280 --> 00:07:39,780
I saw in our chat room, you know, put up,
you know, leave it how you found it or,

138
00:07:39,780 --> 00:07:43,750
you know, Deborah is in the room, nicely
was right on the ball there with it.

139
00:07:43,750 --> 00:07:45,310
You know, leave it how you find it.

140
00:07:45,310 --> 00:07:46,980
Off, leave it off, if it's on.

141
00:07:46,980 --> 00:07:51,420
Leave it on you know that's gonna be
one of the top things on our list.

142
00:07:51,420 --> 00:07:54,050
You know it's making
them familiar with that.

143
00:07:54,050 --> 00:07:59,130
The average person doesn't understand That
and it's not to put anybody down here.

144
00:07:59,130 --> 00:08:02,590
They'd understand how that
impacts our evidence you do.

145
00:08:02,590 --> 00:08:04,690
You don't need to explain
the technical stuff to them.

146
00:08:04,690 --> 00:08:09,537
But you can very well say just don't
touch, hands off, whatever you find,

147
00:08:09,537 --> 00:08:10,615
leave it there.

148
00:08:10,615 --> 00:08:12,365
Wrap a tape around it or whatever.

149
00:08:12,365 --> 00:08:14,925
And call me.

150
00:08:14,925 --> 00:08:17,705
>> Yeah, cuz they don't understand
the validity of some of the data.

151
00:08:17,705 --> 00:08:21,455
Or the volatility, excuse me,

00:57:20,150 --> 00:57:24,560
So, it tells us, okay, here's what we

1009
00:57:24,560 --> 00:57:27,430
How you acquired the information?

They documented
the hardware configuration.

1011

And they tell you right there,

1012
00:57:32,720 --> 00:57:34,470
They're telling you the exact step.

00:57:34,470 --> 00:57:35,780
This is what we did.

1014
00:57:35,780 --> 00:57:38,220
Then they tell you how
they examined everything.

1015
00:57:38,220 --> 00:57:44,350
They looked at file headers, something

1016
00:57:44,350 --> 00:57:49,060
And then, documentation, next steps, and
they just keep going right on through

00:57:49,060 --> 00:57:52,450
this report, and
then they even have other things.

1018

Here's the media analysis.

So, we've got additional things that

1020

So, this went to someone else,
it went to, in this case,

it's being reported to the Sheriff's
office to tell them if

00:58:08,534 --> 00:58:12,820
these are the files we have,
just going right on through.

1023
00:58:12,820 --> 00:58:17,500
I mean, just look at how

1024
00:58:17,500 --> 00:58:20,440
And this is just a minor amount of detail.

1025
00:58:20,440 --> 00:58:22,810
This is just a sample report, remember.

1026
00:58:22,810 --> 00:58:25,522
And then,
there's a glossary with one thing in it.

1027
00:58:25,522 --> 00:58:30,510

I'm D examiner.

00:58:32,496 --> 00:58:35,143
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah, I'm a digital examiner [SOUND].

1031
00:58:35,143 --> 00:58:38,220
>> So,
I think that's the last of piece of it.

1032
00:58:38,220 --> 00:58:40,310
I think they actually have two
reports in here, but yeah,

00:58:40,310 --> 00:58:42,670
I don't need to go into the second one.

1034
00:58:42,670 --> 00:58:47,250
But you can see there was

1035

>> [LAUGH]
>> So, there you go.

You've got a very logical step to step.

00:58:55,800 --> 00:58:58,390
>> And it was nice and

1038
00:58:58,390 --> 00:59:00,800
there wasn't a lot of
extra fluff in there.

1039
00:59:00,800 --> 00:59:03,910
Just by reading the first few

1040
00:59:03,910 --> 00:59:07,440
I got a sense of what the case

1041
00:59:07,440 --> 00:59:09,790
So, it was just very, very nice and tidy.

1042
00:59:09,790 --> 00:59:10,430
I like that.

1043
00:59:10,430 --> 00:59:13,600
>> Yeah, that's the way it should be,
that's what you're looking for.

1044
00:59:13,600 --> 00:59:19,800
And let me tell your, probably, a good

1045
00:59:19,800 --> 00:59:21,415
There's no doubt about this.

1046
00:59:21,415 --> 00:59:23,440
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm sure she's written up some reports.

00:59:23,440 --> 00:59:25,131
Can you provide some

00:59:25,131 --> 00:59:27,971
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm pretty sure everyone wants to see

1050
00:59:29,658 --> 00:59:35,655
But one of the toughest things about
writing a report like this is removing

1051
00:59:35,655 --> 00:59:42,900
your opinion from it
until explicitly needed.

1052
00:59:42,900 --> 00:59:47,990
That is a really,
really tough thing to do.

1053
00:59:47,990 --> 00:59:49,670
It takes practice.

1054
00:59:49,670 --> 00:59:54,420
That's why you have someone read this for

1055
00:59:54,420 --> 00:59:58,810
you and have them see,
is this an opinion or

1056

1057

What do you feel?

1058

If you have trouble doing that,

1059
01:00:08,190 --> 01:00:14,150
I would strongly recommend that you

1060
01:00:14,150 --> 01:00:19,560
Technical writing, that's what they teach
you is like get your opinion out of it and

1061
01:00:19,560 --> 01:00:21,000

1062
01:00:21,000 --> 01:00:25,180
So, if that's what you're
lacking which probably for

1063

a good number of you, not to single
anybody out or pick on anybody,

1064
01:00:29,840 --> 01:00:32,640
for a good number of people,
that is a problem.

1065
01:00:32,640 --> 01:00:36,330
>> So, you will need to, if you're
gonna do this, learn how to do that.

1066
01:00:36,330 --> 01:00:37,890
Either, like I said,

1067
01:00:37,890 --> 01:00:41,630
have someone proofread it and you're
gonna have to practice several times.

1068
01:00:41,630 --> 01:00:45,690
Or just take a course on
technical writing and

1069
01:00:45,690 --> 01:00:48,930
you will learn how to
actually do something,

1070
01:00:48,930 --> 01:00:53,030
write a report that actually gets to the
point and kind of dispenses with the BS.

1071
01:00:53,030 --> 01:00:53,560
>> There you go.

1072
01:00:54,810 --> 01:00:56,960
Well, Sean, that was a great episode.

1073
01:00:56,960 --> 01:01:00,510
We learned all about creating
these reports forward to support

1074
01:01:00,510 --> 01:01:01,548
our investigation.

1075
01:01:01,548 --> 01:01:05,630
How we're gonna go about delivering that,
what needs to be included in that report,

1076
01:01:05,630 --> 01:01:09,410
and then, even some samples of what

1077
01:01:09,410 --> 01:01:12,120
So, anything else we wanna
throw in there for reports?

1078
01:01:13,360 --> 01:01:18,710
>> Not as far as the actual form of
reports, but all of you should remember

1079
01:01:18,710 --> 01:01:23,370
that there's software that will help you
generate this, so you're not on your own.

1080
01:01:23,370 --> 01:01:27,380
It won't do all the work for you but
it can help when you're going through

1081
01:01:27,380 --> 01:01:32,190
the process and time and date stamping
everything and organizing it.

1082
01:01:32,190 --> 01:01:37,276
So, it's easier for
you to put into the proper format.

1083
01:01:37,276 --> 01:01:41,333
So, that's a great thing, and
the software that does some of it,

1084
01:01:41,333 --> 01:01:43,151
you actually have to pay for.

1085
01:01:43,151 --> 01:01:46,202
But heck, paying 500 bucks or
something for

1086
01:01:46,202 --> 01:01:51,081
a piece of software that helps my
documentation process go a little faster,

1087
01:01:51,081 --> 01:01:55,958
yeah, I'm gonna pay for it because I do
not wanna have to go to word and type,

1088
01:01:55,958 --> 01:01:59,510
write everything up from
scratch every time.

1089
01:01:59,510 --> 01:02:00,500
>> Absolutely not.

1090
01:02:00,500 --> 01:02:02,360
>> Yeah.
So, there you go.

1091
01:02:02,360 --> 01:02:04,820
>> Well,
we hope you guys enjoyed this episode.

1092
01:02:04,820 --> 01:02:06,930
Remember, if you were watching

01:02:06,930 --> 01:02:09,530

Up at the top of every page is a Q&A link.

That's gonna take you over to our forums

All of the hosts here at ITProTV,

1099
01:02:24,845 --> 01:02:27,560

1100
01:02:27,560 --> 01:02:32,210
So, again, I hope you enjoyed this show,

episodes.title: Expert Witness
episodes.transcript:
1

2

3

[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,295 --> 00:00:35,869
Good morning, good afternoon and
good evening,

5
00:00:35,869 --> 00:00:37,961
welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:37,961 --> 00:00:40,910
I'm your host Mike Rodrick, and
with me today is Mr. Sean Oriyano.

7
00:00:40,910 --> 00:00:41,950
How you doing Sean?

8
00:00:41,950 --> 00:00:43,060
>> I am doing pretty good.

9
00:00:43,060 --> 00:00:43,740
How you doing today?

10
00:00:43,740 --> 00:00:44,980
>> I am doing fantastic.

11
00:00:44,980 --> 00:00:48,300
We are doing our digital
forensic investigator episodes.

12
00:00:48,300 --> 00:00:53,990
And in this episode we're gonna be
covering becoming an expert witness.

13
00:00:53,990 --> 00:00:58,490
Because at some point during our career,
as a forensic investigator,

14
00:00:58,490 --> 00:01:03,740
we might be called upon to be
a expert witness in a court of law.

15
00:01:03,740 --> 00:01:07,770
>> Yes that's where this is
actually heading is this.

16
00:01:07,770 --> 00:01:12,609
You may become that expert witness
with a little time, experience and

17
00:01:12,609 --> 00:01:17,461
maybe a small amount of luck,
that that will be where you're headed.

18
00:01:17,461 --> 00:01:22,581
So be prepared for that,
you may not just be doing the report,

19
00:01:22,581 --> 00:01:25,842
you may not be just doing the analysis.

20
00:01:25,842 --> 00:01:32,676
You may be going to that next level and
going to court and presenting your facts,

21
00:01:32,676 --> 00:01:37,541
your findings, and
being cross examined and all that.

22
00:01:37,541 --> 00:01:40,128
It can be a frustrating and
stressful experience.

23
00:01:40,128 --> 00:01:43,441
>> I got my suit and tie, I'm ready to go!

24
00:01:43,441 --> 00:01:45,101
But yeah, it really can be.

25
00:01:45,101 --> 00:01:49,861
You do have to be prepared for
this, because it's not just

26
00:01:49,861 --> 00:01:54,391
a matter of you getting up and presenting
information or being asked questions.

27
00:01:54,391 --> 00:01:58,860
On one side of the case, they want
to accept everything you presented.

28
00:01:58,860 --> 00:02:00,980
It proves their side of the case or
whatever.

29
00:02:00,980 --> 00:02:04,540
The other side, though, is going to
try to take everything you've done and

30
00:02:04,540 --> 00:02:08,260
tear it apart, poke holes in it and
destroy, not destroy, but

31
00:02:08,260 --> 00:02:12,650
to poke at your expertise, maybe, or
your reputation and things like that.

32
00:02:12,650 --> 00:02:16,380
So it can be a very, very stressful,
I know people that don't wanna do it.

33
00:02:16,380 --> 00:02:18,420
I mean they love being
a forensic investigator, or

34
00:02:18,420 --> 00:02:22,190
they love doing what they do, but
they don't want to be a witness in court.

35
00:02:22,190 --> 00:02:26,100
>> Yeah, I wouldn't blame them, there's

36
00:02:26,100 --> 00:02:30,821
people that already get sweaty hands, and
dry mouth just by going in the court,

37
00:02:30,821 --> 00:02:32,888
[LAUGH] and that might just be for
a traffic ticket.

38
00:02:32,888 --> 00:02:34,550
>> [LAUGH]
>> I mean can you imagine actually sitting

39
00:02:34,550 --> 00:02:37,760
on the stand and
have to be grilled by somebody.

40
00:02:37,760 --> 00:02:42,370
First, there's somebody that's friendly to
you and then there's someone that's gonna

41
00:02:42,370 --> 00:02:47,442
be really hostile to you and try to rip
your throat out and make you look bad.

42
00:02:47,442 --> 00:02:51,835
So yeah, it could be very,
very, very stressful,

43
00:02:51,835 --> 00:02:54,135
and to be honest not everyone's suited for
it.

44
00:02:54,135 --> 00:02:55,425
>> Not everybody is cut out for it.

45
00:02:55,425 --> 00:02:57,655
So the first thing we
really should do Shawn,

46
00:02:57,655 --> 00:03:01,525
is define what we mean
by an expert witness.

47
00:03:01,525 --> 00:03:02,770
We're all probably.

48
00:03:02,770 --> 00:03:04,510
Have our own thoughts of what that means.

49
00:03:04,510 --> 00:03:07,660
We've seen enough crime shows and
things like that but

50
00:03:07,660 --> 00:03:11,160
let's really define you know
what makes an expert witness.

51
00:03:11,160 --> 00:03:14,140
>> An expert witness is
someone that really just

52
00:03:14,140 --> 00:03:18,980
is recognized as being someone that's
very knowledgeable about their field and

53
00:03:18,980 --> 00:03:22,260
that would be true with anybody
that you're going to consider and

54
00:03:22,260 --> 00:03:25,500
expert witness is somebody that's
knowledgeable in their field.

55
00:03:25,500 --> 00:03:30,680
So if just for
as an example those of you that

56
00:03:30,680 --> 00:03:34,420
have experience in IT,
several years experience.

57
00:03:34,420 --> 00:03:39,060
If you were called in to testify about
something or provide your opinion or

58
00:03:39,060 --> 00:03:41,870
testify something about networks.

59
00:03:41,870 --> 00:03:45,940
You might be considered with
your knowledge, certifications,

60
00:03:45,940 --> 00:03:48,753
experience to be an expert
witness in there.

61
00:03:48,753 --> 00:03:51,786
You know, so
that would be one way to approach it,

62
00:03:51,786 --> 00:03:54,966
in the case of someone
that's a forensic examiner,

63
00:03:54,966 --> 00:03:59,590
they're gonna look at your experience,
how long you've been doing this,

64
00:03:59,590 --> 00:04:05,330
you know maybe what you've worked on, you
know things that you may have published.

65
00:04:05,330 --> 00:04:10,090
And all those things will go towards,
yes you've got verifiable experience.

66
00:04:10,090 --> 00:04:13,990
You've actually been paid to do this type
of stuff before, so you're a professional.

67
00:04:13,990 --> 00:04:18,740
And that is a detail, by the way,
to be considered an expert in something,

68
00:04:18,740 --> 00:04:20,810
they're gonna say have you been paid for
this?

69
00:04:20,810 --> 00:04:24,520
You just can't say oh, I watch a lot
of CSI and read a lot of books, so

70
00:04:24,520 --> 00:04:25,180
I'm an expert.

71
00:04:25,180 --> 00:04:28,100
>> I do this as a hobby on the weekend,
or something like that.

72
00:04:28,100 --> 00:04:30,630
That's probably not gonna fly.

73
00:04:30,630 --> 00:04:35,380
>> You could be real good at this stuff,
but, just self taught and

74
00:04:35,380 --> 00:04:40,160
gotten certified and all that type of
stuff, but if you haven't be paid for

75
00:04:40,160 --> 00:04:44,430
it means that your skills aren't
worth someone to pay for.

76
00:04:44,430 --> 00:04:47,560
So that would be a big bump in

77
00:04:49,340 --> 00:04:53,910
the road towards your getting
certified as an expert witness.

78
00:04:53,910 --> 00:04:56,000
And then I even see this
one with Mikayla as,

79
00:04:56,000 --> 00:04:59,330
you need PhD level qualifications
to be considered an expert witness.

80
00:04:59,330 --> 00:05:01,442
No.
No you don't.

81
00:05:01,442 --> 00:05:08,210
There's a select set of criteria
generally accepted, if you meet those.

82
00:05:08,210 --> 00:05:13,020
You can be considered an expert witness,
but you don't have to be.

83
00:05:13,020 --> 00:05:17,590
I mean an auto mechanic can be considered
an expert witness if there was a case that

84
00:05:17,590 --> 00:05:19,330
needed that expertise.

85
00:05:19,330 --> 00:05:22,630
You can call someone in that's an auto
mechanic and had been doing that for

86
00:05:22,630 --> 00:05:24,550
the last 20 years.

87
00:05:24,550 --> 00:05:28,620
Down at some auto repair place.

88
00:05:28,620 --> 00:05:29,870
They've clearly been paid for

89
00:05:29,870 --> 00:05:34,240
it, they clearly know their stuff,
they've got a long track record.

90
00:05:35,480 --> 00:05:36,400
They're an expert witness.

91
00:05:36,400 --> 00:05:38,490
>> Absolutely.
>> They will be recognized as that.

92
00:05:38,490 --> 00:05:42,110
You're not gonna get a PHD
in auto maintenance.

93
00:05:42,110 --> 00:05:43,310
It just doesn't happen.

94
00:05:43,310 --> 00:05:46,350
>> Yeah it really depends on what it
is they're looking for an expert in.

95
00:05:46,350 --> 00:05:49,090
If it was a doctor
>> Then we're gonna require that they've

96
00:05:49,090 --> 00:05:50,340
gone to medical school.

97
00:05:50,340 --> 00:05:55,180
Both sides need to agree that this person
is an expert in whatever field it is.

98
00:05:55,180 --> 00:05:58,160
I mean my mother will tell you that
I'm an expert as a procrastinator,

99
00:05:58,160 --> 00:06:01,020
I've got 46 years of
experience procrastinating.

100
00:06:01,020 --> 00:06:03,930
I've never been paid for it and
I've never written any books on it so

101
00:06:03,930 --> 00:06:07,330
it'd be difficult probably for
me to become an expert witness in that.

102
00:06:07,330 --> 00:06:09,150
>> But he is getting around to the books,
tomorrow.

103
00:06:09,150 --> 00:06:11,568
>> [LAUGH] I'm getting around to them,
that's right.

104
00:06:11,568 --> 00:06:12,795
[LAUGH] Tomorrow.

105
00:06:12,795 --> 00:06:14,573
>> Yeah.

106
00:06:14,573 --> 00:06:18,460
All right, so an expert witness is
just somebody that everybody agrees,

107
00:06:18,460 --> 00:06:24,370
has certain qualifications or the ability
to prove their knowledge in the field.

108
00:06:24,370 --> 00:06:26,960
And we'll talk about
some of the specifics of

109
00:06:26,960 --> 00:06:29,490
what qualifications are in just a minute.

110
00:06:29,490 --> 00:06:31,720
And what is their role in a case.

111
00:06:31,720 --> 00:06:34,080
What it was the expert
witness called upon to do?

112
00:06:35,100 --> 00:06:40,730
>> The expert witness is gonna
be somebody that is going to

113
00:06:40,730 --> 00:06:46,160
be on the stand,
is gonna be questioned about findings,

114
00:06:46,160 --> 00:06:51,930
about reports, about specifics of
the case, about their opinion.

115
00:06:51,930 --> 00:06:55,740
That type of stuff is where
they will come in, and

116
00:06:55,740 --> 00:07:00,590
their role in the court room would be is
that they're expected to provide this

117
00:07:00,590 --> 00:07:05,820
extra real time investigation,
analysis of this.

118
00:07:05,820 --> 00:07:08,842
And yeah, they will be grilled,
they could be sitting on the stand for

119
00:07:08,842 --> 00:07:12,560
a while, and
they're there to be your expert.

120
00:07:12,560 --> 00:07:17,333
If questions are asked, if you need the
extra help, if you feel that having that

121
00:07:17,333 --> 00:07:22,336
analysis is going to boost your position,
then, that's what their role is to do.

122
00:07:22,336 --> 00:07:23,890
>> Okay.
And then not everybody,

123
00:07:23,890 --> 00:07:25,740
as we said at the beginning
of this episode,

124
00:07:25,740 --> 00:07:28,190
not everybody makes a good expert witness.

125
00:07:28,190 --> 00:07:29,980
They might have the qualifications.

126
00:07:29,980 --> 00:07:34,360
They might have the knowledge, the
experience, publish books in the subject,

127
00:07:34,360 --> 00:07:35,360
and things like that.

128
00:07:35,360 --> 00:07:37,110
And still not be chosen
as an expert witness.

129
00:07:37,110 --> 00:07:38,970
Right?
Cuz there are certain things that make

>> And we'll see you next time.

episodes.transcript:
1

2

[SOUND]

3
00:00:33,279 --> 00:00:34,924
>> Good morning,
good afternoon and good evening.

4
00:00:34,924 --> 00:00:37,250
Welcome to another episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:37,250 --> 00:00:39,130
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

6
00:00:39,130 --> 00:00:42,420
And with me today is Mr.
Sean Oriyano, how are you doing Sean?

7
00:00:42,420 --> 00:00:43,550
>> I'm pretty good, how are you doing?

8
00:00:43,550 --> 00:00:45,590
>> I'm fantastic, glad to be here.

9
00:00:45,590 --> 00:00:49,850
We are shooting our digital
forensic investigator episodes.

10
00:00:49,850 --> 00:00:51,760
We wanted to take a minute, step back, and

11
00:00:51,760 --> 00:00:53,800
kind of go outside of our course for
a minute.

12
00:00:53,800 --> 00:00:58,040
We've been talking a lot about collecting
evidence and obtaining warrants and

13
00:00:58,040 --> 00:00:59,450
things like that.

14
00:00:59,450 --> 00:01:01,630
And times are changing, right Sean?

15
00:01:01,630 --> 00:01:06,786
They used to be that everything was in
my local area network, or maybe across

16
00:01:06,786 --> 00:01:11,958
the WAN, to a branch office or other
private networks and things like that.

17
00:01:11,958 --> 00:01:13,193
Nowadays though,

18
00:01:13,193 --> 00:01:18,380
we've got this new area that we have
got to be able to work with, right?

19
00:01:18,380 --> 00:01:19,340
>> Yes.

20
00:01:19,340 --> 00:01:24,680
There's interesting technologies that come
out all of the time and so we have to talk

21
00:01:24,680 --> 00:01:30,200
about one of those things that is gonna
impact your life and that's the cloud.

22
00:01:30,200 --> 00:01:32,890
It's what a lot of you
are already dealing with, or

23
00:01:32,890 --> 00:01:35,680
will deal with in the near future.

24
00:01:35,680 --> 00:01:39,400
>> It really changes thing dramatically
when it comes to doing forensic

25
00:01:39,400 --> 00:01:41,650
investigations, doesn't it?

26
00:01:41,650 --> 00:01:46,140
>> Oh yeah,
it has a tremendous impact on how

27
00:01:46,140 --> 00:01:51,950
investigations are gonna take place and
what the extents and responsibilities are.

28
00:01:51,950 --> 00:01:53,100
Just a ton.

29
00:01:54,310 --> 00:01:57,090
And they're still feeling this out,
it's still developing.

30
00:01:57,090 --> 00:01:59,860
>> That's the thing is we're just
now trying to figure out how we

31
00:01:59,860 --> 00:02:03,050
go about this and
how we deal with it, right?

32
00:02:03,050 --> 00:02:04,680
And to give you guys some background,

33
00:02:04,680 --> 00:02:07,040
you guys should be familiar with
this at this point in your career.

34
00:02:07,040 --> 00:02:10,780
Anyway, when we talk about the cloud
we could be talking about public hosted

35
00:02:10,780 --> 00:02:16,090
clouds like Amazon Web Services,
or Microsoft's Azure,

36
00:02:16,090 --> 00:02:19,870
or something like that, where we're
leasing space from some organization.

37
00:02:19,870 --> 00:02:22,690
They're maintaining the servers,
or providing the platform,

38
00:02:22,690 --> 00:02:24,320
or maybe just the application.

39
00:02:24,320 --> 00:02:27,352
But the point is, is those servers
are outside of my organization being

40
00:02:27,352 --> 00:02:30,091
maintained by somebody else and
accessible from the internet?

41
00:02:30,091 --> 00:02:32,287
Could be private cloud scenarios,

42
00:02:32,287 --> 00:02:36,021
where we're making that
information available from inside

43
00:02:36,021 --> 00:02:41,270
an organization out to the internet,
or to extranets, and things like that.

44
00:02:41,270 --> 00:02:45,270
And so Sean, when we talk about there's
this public cloud primarily and/or

45
00:02:45,270 --> 00:02:48,370
the private cloud,
what is it that's different?

46
00:02:48,370 --> 00:02:51,020
Why does this change things so much?

47
00:02:51,020 --> 00:02:54,460
>> Well, the thing that actually changes
the cloud is if you think about the nature

48
00:02:54,460 --> 00:02:58,130
of the way the cloud works is that yes,
you can have stuff stored out there, you

49
00:02:58,130 --> 00:03:03,490
can have infrastructure out there, you can
have other services hosted in the cloud.

50
00:03:03,490 --> 00:03:07,330
So already you have taken
stuff outside of your

51
00:03:07,330 --> 00:03:12,290
responsibility as a company if we look at
it from that angle, to some place else.

52
00:03:12,290 --> 00:03:16,630
If you're doing a forensic investigation,
now what happens is if you're targeting

53
00:03:16,630 --> 00:03:23,380
a company for some sort of behavior and
you want to extract data, if you find that

54
00:03:23,380 --> 00:03:28,280
the data has been stored someplace else
the search warrant isn't gonna cover that.

55
00:03:28,280 --> 00:03:29,430
That's someplace else.

56
00:03:29,430 --> 00:03:30,157
Typically it's not gonna cover that.

57
00:03:30,157 --> 00:03:35,016
At least right now, that's not included
in search warrants which means you have

58
00:03:35,016 --> 00:03:40,180
to get another search warrant to get
permission to do any investigation there.

59
00:03:40,180 --> 00:03:43,110
>> Yeah.
The warrant I obtained to search this

60
00:03:44,340 --> 00:03:49,380
target's house is not gonna cover
Microsoft servers out there in Azure.

61
00:03:49,380 --> 00:03:53,880
If I'm in a corporation,
my company might be able to give me

62
00:03:53,880 --> 00:03:58,030
access to their machine, to our file
servers on our corporate network.

63
00:03:58,030 --> 00:04:01,920
But probably doesn't have the authority
to give me permissions to go in and

64
00:04:01,920 --> 00:04:06,055
start searching for evidence on web
services or something like that.

65
00:04:06,055 --> 00:04:09,935
So, that poses a big problem,
now we've gotta go back and

66
00:04:09,935 --> 00:04:14,205
make sure we get the right warrants, we
have to get separate for this kinda stuff.

67
00:04:14,205 --> 00:04:17,195
And another thing that
the cloud throws in there is,

68
00:04:17,195 --> 00:04:20,885
if it's public cloud, you're not
the only one on those servers, right?

69
00:04:20,885 --> 00:04:24,365
These are multi tenant
cloud service providers.

70
00:04:24,365 --> 00:04:27,390
So I'm gonna have to worry
about that as well, right?

71
00:04:27,390 --> 00:04:30,878
>> Yeah.
That's actually an immense concern about

72
00:04:30,878 --> 00:04:36,402
how we work with the cloud is, first of
all, if you're going to go out there and

73
00:04:36,402 --> 00:04:41,343
grab data or try to grab evidence,
you're gonna have an issue there if

74
00:04:41,343 --> 00:04:45,110
you try to grab a whole computer or
server out of that,

75
00:04:45,110 --> 00:04:51,210
because it really doesn't exist that way,
that's not the way the cloud works.

76
00:04:51,210 --> 00:04:54,010
And if you were able to say, okay,
I'm gonna grab enough of this or

77
00:04:54,010 --> 00:05:00,210
seize this facility or
whatever to do this investigation,

78
00:05:00,210 --> 00:05:04,560
they're gonna impact other people that
are not part of this investigation.

79
00:05:04,560 --> 00:05:06,330
If you try to do something on that scale,

80
00:05:06,330 --> 00:05:08,750
so that's pretty much
out of the picture too.

81
00:05:08,750 --> 00:05:12,980
And then we get other
things that come into play.

82
00:05:12,980 --> 00:05:17,610
If you do forensics,
just how do forensics work

83
00:05:17,610 --> 00:05:22,150
in the cloud if we're gonna
do things like file recovery?

84
00:05:22,150 --> 00:05:26,770
That would be an interesting
thing to happen,

85
00:05:26,770 --> 00:05:31,150
when you look at how the cloud works,
when it resizes stuff and

86
00:05:31,150 --> 00:05:36,200
allocates it for stuff as needed,
that's gonna have an impact on

87
00:05:36,200 --> 00:05:39,760
how you recover deleted data
if you're looking for that.

88
00:05:39,760 --> 00:05:41,550
So, a lot of stuff.

89
00:05:41,550 --> 00:05:43,830
>> Absolutely, and
we got a great comment in the chatroom,

90
00:05:43,830 --> 00:05:46,110
which is kinda leading
right where I was headed.

91
00:05:46,110 --> 00:05:48,760
Deborah asks, since a server can be
registered anywhere in the world,

92
00:05:48,760 --> 00:05:52,510
can be located physically somewhere else,
trying to determine the jurisdiction and

93
00:05:52,510 --> 00:05:56,180
if evidence can be obtained from
an ISP will be more difficult.

94
00:05:56,180 --> 00:05:57,560
And absolutely.

95
00:05:57,560 --> 00:06:01,930
Because these cloud providers could have
server farms located around the world.

96
00:06:01,930 --> 00:06:06,030
We've gotta deal with international laws
and just trying to determine who it is I

97
00:06:06,030 --> 00:06:11,920
need to talk to about possibly compelling
them to give me that evidence.

98
00:06:11,920 --> 00:06:13,150
It becomes an issue.

99
00:06:13,150 --> 00:06:18,190
>> Yeah, that's a massive snag waiting
to happen if you run into that where

100
00:06:18,190 --> 00:06:22,160
you're somewhere here in the US,
let's say, and

101
00:06:22,160 --> 00:06:27,890
the cloud provider you have is hosting
their stuff in India let's say,

102
00:06:27,890 --> 00:06:32,010
that's gonna be a mess, right there.

103
00:06:32,010 --> 00:06:36,960
Now there's ways that those
situations may be setup that

104
00:06:36,960 --> 00:06:41,980
lend themselves better to you being
able to get a search warrant, or

105
00:06:41,980 --> 00:06:43,840
being able to do any sort
of investigation on it.

106
00:06:43,840 --> 00:06:46,640
But it's gonna be very, very, very tough.

107
00:06:46,640 --> 00:06:50,920
And in fact, interestingly enough,
some of the contracts that you see that

108
00:06:50,920 --> 00:06:55,860
are signed with cloud providers or
clients request to be signed with cloud

109
00:06:55,860 --> 00:07:01,000
providers, specifically
mention a way to do forensics.

110
00:07:01,000 --> 00:07:04,780
And it's really something
there that has no teeth.

111
00:07:04,780 --> 00:07:09,080
There's really no way to effectively do
it with the situation they've been given.

112
00:07:09,080 --> 00:07:12,120
It's different if you have a private
cloud, because you host everything and

113
00:07:12,120 --> 00:07:14,380
you've got a little more control over it.

114
00:07:14,380 --> 00:07:17,500
But, yeah, once you start going
international and stuff like that,

115
00:07:17,500 --> 00:07:19,230
that changes things dramatically.

116
00:07:19,230 --> 00:07:24,190
You can't ask for the same searches, you
can't do the same investigations on it.

117
00:07:24,190 --> 00:07:27,150
That definitely changes things a lot.

118
00:07:27,150 --> 00:07:30,894
That's why some governments
will say the cloud,

119
00:07:30,894 --> 00:07:36,879
if you're gonna use cloud technology,
they have to be hosted in a certain way.

120
00:07:36,879 --> 00:07:41,559
Here in the US,
it's federal government stuff, for

121
00:07:41,559 --> 00:07:45,420
example, has to be stored within the US.

122
00:07:45,420 --> 00:07:48,280
It cannot go overseas anyplace.

123
00:07:49,460 --> 00:07:52,970
>> So we're gonna make sure we talk and we
could be verifying with that cloud service

124
00:07:52,970 --> 00:07:57,730
provider that they are hosting
that data locally in our country.

125
00:07:57,730 --> 00:07:58,870
We've got a few issues, right?

126
00:07:58,870 --> 00:08:01,810
We've already brought up
with this cloud services.

127
00:08:01,810 --> 00:08:05,690
Seizing those files could
include information from people

128
00:08:05,690 --> 00:08:07,550
outside of the scope of my investigation.

129
00:08:07,550 --> 00:08:09,620
And now, I've got privacy concerns.

130
00:08:09,620 --> 00:08:10,980
Issues to deal with there.

131
00:08:13,550 --> 00:08:16,740
We're compelling those passwords'

132
00:08:16,740 --> 00:08:19,270
providers to provide this information for
us.

133
00:08:19,270 --> 00:08:21,470
How trusty is that cloud provider, right?

134
00:08:21,470 --> 00:08:23,020
Are they giving us all the information?

135
00:08:23,020 --> 00:08:25,130
Are they giving us accurate information?

136
00:08:25,130 --> 00:08:27,240
Who did they use to
collect that information?

137
00:08:27,240 --> 00:08:28,670
Are they certified?

138
00:08:28,670 --> 00:08:29,930
Are they trained technicians?

139
00:08:29,930 --> 00:08:34,450
Is this data gonna hold up in a court
of law even if I do get it from them?

140
00:08:34,450 --> 00:08:39,470
>> Yeah, there's so many concerns when
you're hosting it someplace away from

141
00:08:41,720 --> 00:08:44,110
your own infrastructure.

142
00:08:44,110 --> 00:08:48,730
So if someone else has it under
their control, so if you look at

143
00:08:48,730 --> 00:08:53,050
that just right there, you're
putting your stuff in someone else's

144
00:08:57,620 --> 00:09:00,390
control in their server center,
whatever you want to call it.

145
00:09:00,390 --> 00:09:02,720
They have it sitting there, and

146
00:09:02,720 --> 00:09:07,340
they're controlling it and keeping
it healthy for you on their servers.

147
00:09:07,340 --> 00:09:13,650
Can they say if the law enforcement comes
in and says, we need to look at this?

148
00:09:13,650 --> 00:09:16,210
Is there a situation there
where they can do that,

149
00:09:16,210 --> 00:09:22,000
kind of that third party authorization
that we talked about where if I take

150
00:09:22,000 --> 00:09:27,800
my notebook to a computer repair store and
they find something.

151
00:09:27,800 --> 00:09:32,850
They can call the police themselves and
authorize certain things to happen.

152
00:09:32,850 --> 00:09:34,441
Can that cloud provider do that?

153
00:09:34,441 --> 00:09:36,655
That's been a question.

154
00:09:36,655 --> 00:09:40,650
The answer to it seems to be no.

155
00:09:40,650 --> 00:09:43,599
But, there is a reason why
I said seems to be no.

156
00:09:43,599 --> 00:09:45,660
>> [LAUGH] All right.

157
00:09:45,660 --> 00:09:46,895
>> Your mileage may vary.

158
00:09:46,895 --> 00:09:48,030
[LAUGH]
>> As we've said,

159
00:09:48,030 --> 00:09:50,200
this is all within the last few years.

160
00:09:50,200 --> 00:09:53,060
Really becoming a problem
that we had to deal with.

161
00:09:53,060 --> 00:09:55,140
There scenarios that
we've had to deal with.

162
00:09:55,140 --> 00:09:58,860
So the laws are still catching up,
the procedures are still catching up,

163
00:09:58,860 --> 00:10:01,540
the techniques that we use
are still being developed.

164
00:10:01,540 --> 00:10:05,550
So it's great being on that cutting edge,
but

165
00:10:05,550 --> 00:10:09,575
at the same time sometimes it's not so
fun being on that cutting edge.

166
00:10:09,575 --> 00:10:11,836
So, I gotta figure out how
we can deal with that.

167
00:10:11,836 --> 00:10:13,381
>> Cutting edge can be
the bleeding edge really quickly.

168
00:10:13,381 --> 00:10:17,670
>> Exactly.
So just something that we think you guys

169
00:10:17,670 --> 00:10:26,007
should consider or have to think about
as a digital forensic investigator.

170
00:10:26,007 --> 00:10:27,577
How does the cloud change things?

171
00:10:27,577 --> 00:10:33,303
How does me investigating a scenario or
situation if that points to the cloud?

172
00:10:33,303 --> 00:10:37,033
Does that change my procedures and
the way I handle things.

173
00:10:37,033 --> 00:10:38,253
And it absolutely does.

174
00:10:38,253 --> 00:10:40,853
It's something that we
have to deal with so.

175
00:10:40,853 --> 00:10:44,453
And we got a few great links we're gonna
post in the show notes to let you do some

176
00:10:44,453 --> 00:10:49,033
additional reading on
these topics as well.

177
00:10:50,133 --> 00:10:53,093
>> Ben brings up a good thing here,
it says your service level agreement,

178
00:10:53,093 --> 00:10:56,890
your SLA should state where
your cloud information is held.

179
00:10:56,890 --> 00:11:02,270
And you say for programmers and
developers, well,

180
00:11:02,270 --> 00:11:08,220
forget the programmer and developer
situation, just apply it to everybody.

181
00:11:08,220 --> 00:11:13,980
Yeah, you're gonna have an SLA that
comes with your cloud service.

182
00:11:13,980 --> 00:11:17,890
One of the problems that has been
encountered a lot with hosting in

183
00:11:17,890 --> 00:11:26,760
the cloud, and going to a cloud provider
is that you purchase the service,

184
00:11:26,760 --> 00:11:31,630
they give you an SLA, but
you don't investigate it too closely,

185
00:11:31,630 --> 00:11:34,870
which is really your fault
if you're not doing that.

186
00:11:34,870 --> 00:11:38,840
But is that they also don't
inform you of certain things.

187
00:11:38,840 --> 00:11:43,060
Some hosting providers, they only
provide just the hosting service.

188
00:11:43,060 --> 00:11:46,670
Just the basically from
the hypervisor down.

189
00:11:46,670 --> 00:11:48,650
Everything else up above that's on you.

190
00:11:48,650 --> 00:11:50,720
That means if things need to be backed up,

191
00:11:50,720 --> 00:11:54,480
that's on you unless you
ask them to do it for you.

192
00:11:54,480 --> 00:11:56,885
And so, you have to pay extra for that.

193
00:11:56,885 --> 00:12:01,260
So, and
not all of them will tell you that either.

194
00:12:01,260 --> 00:12:05,950
Because a lot of people that sell
cloud services, they're not IT people,

195
00:12:05,950 --> 00:12:07,510
they are salespeople.

196
00:12:07,510 --> 00:12:12,200
They hear all this nice terms
about what the cloud is, and

197
00:12:12,200 --> 00:12:14,790
how great it is, and
all this awesome stuff.

198
00:12:14,790 --> 00:12:19,150
They're not thinking of the technical
issues that sit behind that.

199
00:12:19,150 --> 00:12:21,438
So you really have to kind
of ask those questions.

200
00:12:21,438 --> 00:12:28,575
If you start stirring in stuff like,
what if you're a healthcare company?

201
00:12:28,575 --> 00:12:33,640
I always use those as an example
because they got stringent rules.

202
00:12:33,640 --> 00:12:39,230
That changes your SLA, and
your evidence collection all dramatically.

203
00:12:39,230 --> 00:12:44,870
So there's a lot of stuff that very
well could be happening there.

204
00:12:44,870 --> 00:12:46,460
>> Yeah, absolutely.

205
00:12:46,460 --> 00:12:49,910
Some other things that we have
to deal with cloud providers and

206
00:12:49,910 --> 00:12:53,360
our forensic investigations
is a long synchronization.

207
00:12:53,360 --> 00:12:56,390
Or time synchronization is
really what it comes back to.

208
00:12:56,390 --> 00:12:59,167
If you've sat through our server
episodes or anything like that,

209
00:12:59,167 --> 00:13:01,520
you're familiar with time synchronization.

210
00:13:01,520 --> 00:13:04,740
And in house all my computers
are synchronized with

211
00:13:04,740 --> 00:13:07,790
a particular machine on my network,
my PDC emulator,

212
00:13:07,790 --> 00:13:12,020
and that keeps the sync times
synchronized across all the machines.

213
00:13:12,020 --> 00:13:16,590
So in the event of an investigation,
I can start correlating log files.

214
00:13:16,590 --> 00:13:20,090
I'm trying to correlate log files off
my routing devices and my file servers,

215
00:13:20,090 --> 00:13:24,810
or the machine that
the attacker was using.

216
00:13:24,810 --> 00:13:27,741
Whoever it is I'm investigating was using,
I can correlate these log files.

217
00:13:27,741 --> 00:13:30,139
I can see when things were happening at
the same time on two different nodes,

218
00:13:30,139 --> 00:13:30,708
or what have you.

219
00:13:30,708 --> 00:13:36,700
With the cloud services,
those hosts are not a part of my network.

220
00:13:36,700 --> 00:13:38,780
They're not synchronizing
their time with me, or

221
00:13:38,780 --> 00:13:41,020
I'm not synchronizing my time with them.

222
00:13:41,020 --> 00:13:44,310
So, those machines that I'm
running up there on their network

223
00:13:44,310 --> 00:13:48,520
are not synchronizing their time and so
that's gonna make synchronizing those

224
00:13:48,520 --> 00:13:52,230
log file trying to do that log
analysis much more difficult as well.

225
00:13:53,290 --> 00:13:54,380
>> Yeah.

226
00:13:54,380 --> 00:13:59,220
There's so many cans of worms
that can potentially open.

227
00:13:59,220 --> 00:14:03,510
I even see James in here saying, is it
possible I can start at local level and

It was just a big thing, so yeah.

00:14:54,000 --> 00:14:59,640
That progressed from literally

00:14:59,640 --> 00:15:01,260

285

286
00:17:38,390 --> 00:17:39,130
>> Absolutely.

287
00:17:39,130 --> 00:17:43,847
So, I hope we open your guys' eyes up to

288
00:17:43,847 --> 00:17:44,970
investigation.

289
00:17:44,970 --> 00:17:49,463
The cloud changes a lot of things, and

our mindset when we go and

We're not seeing a ton

That has to be addressed or

299
00:18:28,160 --> 00:18:35,030
So if you're not really fluent in
the cloud, yet as both an IT person and

300
00:18:35,030 --> 00:18:39,070
as someone that's gonna be doing
forensics, that's what your goal is by

301
00:18:39,070 --> 00:18:43,950

302
00:18:43,950 --> 00:18:44,860
>> It's time.

303
00:18:44,860 --> 00:18:46,260
It's time.

304

All right, well ladies and

Just wanted to give you
a little bit of a food for

00:18:51,180 --> 00:18:54,660

So, signing off for

26

27

We spent time determining

Not only did that time that we

And by having that knowledge

So, it's all about gaining that knowledge,

00:03:13,538 --> 00:03:18,126
When they say common mistakes, obviously

00:03:19,440 --> 00:03:22,160
As long as we understand,

So what are some of the common mistakes

55
00:03:28,006 --> 00:03:31,270

Another one is not documenting the crime

57
00:03:35,820 --> 00:03:36,750

58
00:03:36,750 --> 00:03:40,870
You want to preserve it when you
get out there because you only

60
00:03:43,980 --> 00:03:44,990
It's the same thing,

61
00:03:44,990 --> 00:03:49,950
is you only get one chance to document

62
00:03:49,950 --> 00:03:53,070
So, you really wanna do things thoroughly.

63

Notice when we were talking about this,

None of that.

Take thousand of pictures if you have to.

Like I said, better to over-document and

Murphy's Law is probably gonna say

>> It's one of the reasons also why you

because it is easy to make

Once you get more skilled it

00:04:48,220 --> 00:04:52,460
kinda go through a procedure

[LAUGH] Ask what's on

what we thought might have

00:05:46,910 --> 00:05:47,820
So we wanna get there,

Before everything starts getting moved,

We might be,

00:06:04,620 --> 00:06:07,060
By that point, people have been

00:06:07,060 --> 00:06:09,450
So you want to capture

00:06:09,450 --> 00:06:11,650

00:06:11,650 --> 00:06:14,600

00:06:14,600 --> 00:06:16,650

00:06:16,650 --> 00:06:19,150

00:06:19,150 --> 00:06:19,720

One of the things that you want

00:06:28,810 --> 00:06:30,430

00:06:30,430 --> 00:06:33,200
And you want to know that ahead of time.

00:06:33,200 --> 00:06:38,190
It was already, you know,
kinda peaked out a few times in here, but

00:06:38,190 --> 00:06:40,230
I can't emphasize it enough.

117
00:06:40,230 --> 00:06:42,460
Know who you're supposed
to communicate to.

118
00:06:42,460 --> 00:06:46,840
Introduce yourself to the different
resources you might have.

119
00:06:46,840 --> 00:06:54,505
Get to establish a hotline with your
local FBI office if you need to.

120
00:06:54,505 --> 00:07:00,957
Get those things in place so
people know who each other is.

121
00:07:00,957 --> 00:07:03,257
Know who to be talking to.

122
00:07:03,257 --> 00:07:07,817
And when things are ready to go,
we've got them.

123
00:07:07,817 --> 00:07:09,117
We've got all those things in place.

124
00:07:09,117 --> 00:07:11,067
So always know who you're
supposed to talk to,

125
00:07:11,067 --> 00:07:13,670
have good clear lines of communication.

126
00:07:13,670 --> 00:07:18,640
Don't just start passing stuff around,

127
00:07:18,640 --> 00:07:19,700
>> Yeah, and you're gonna have,

as we've said, at this crime scene

00:07:26,920 --> 00:07:30,440

00:07:30,440 --> 00:07:33,590

00:07:37,120 --> 00:07:40,890
You know communication between

00:07:40,890 --> 00:07:44,320
can help to make sure that

136
00:07:44,320 --> 00:07:50,690
And you don't want maybe
a police officer or an EMT just

00:07:50,690 --> 00:07:54,390

138
00:07:54,390 --> 00:07:55,475
Make sure they know that, hey,

00:07:57,490 --> 00:07:59,440

00:07:59,440 --> 00:08:01,612
>> Yeah, exactly.

The stuff has to be handled a certain way.

143

And so, make sure they're [LAUGH]
aware of where things are.

144
00:08:07,666 --> 00:08:12,752
You may very well be the one that is
gonna be in control of that scene and

145
00:08:12,752 --> 00:08:16,010

146
00:08:16,010 --> 00:08:17,995
Expect to be in that position.

147
00:08:17,995 --> 00:08:19,980
>> Mm-hm absolutely.

00:25:48,190 --> 00:25:51,400

00:25:51,400 --> 00:25:56,370
Help that whole process that's its
one purpose in life to do that.

00:25:56,370 --> 00:25:57,190
